Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Frontier: Collaborative Research: BioCPS for Engineering Living Cells

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent developments in nanotechnology and synthetic biology have enabled a new direction in biological engineering: synthesis of collective behaviors and spatio-temporal patterns in multi-cellular bacterial and mammalian systems. This will have a dramatic impact in such areas as amorphous computing, nano-fabrication, and, in particular, tissue engineering, where patterns can be used to differentiate stem cells into tissues and organs. While recent technologies such as tissue- and organoid on-a-chip have the potential to produce a paradigm shift in tissue engineering and drug development, the synthesis of user-specified, emergent behaviors in cell populations is a key step to unlock this potential and remains a challenging, unsolved problem.

This project brings together synthetic biology and micron-scale mobile robotics to define the basis of a next-generation cyber-physical system (CPS) called biological CPS (bioCPS). Synthetic gene circuits for decision making and local communication among the cells are automatically synthesized using a Bio-Design Automation (BDA) workflow. A Robot Assistant for Communication, Sensing, and Control in Cellular Networks (RA), which is designed and built as part of this project, is used to generate desired patterns in networks of engineered cells. In RA, the engineered cells interact with a set of micro-robots that implement control, sensing, and long-range communication strategies needed to achieve the desired global behavior. The micro-robots include both living and non-living matter (engineered cells attached to inorganic substrates that can be controlled using externally applied fields). This technology is applied to test the formation of various patterns in living cells.

The project has a rich education and outreach plan, which includes nationwide activities for CPS education of high-school students, lab tours and competitions for high-school and undergraduate students, workshops, seminars, and courses for graduate students, as well as specific initiatives for under-represented groups. Central to the project is the development of theory and computational tools that will significantly advance that state of the art in CPS at large. A novel, formal methods approach is proposed for synthesis of emergent, global behaviors in large collections of locally interacting agents. In particular, a new logic whose formulas can be efficiently learned from quad-tree representations of partitioned images is developed. The quantitative semantics of the logic maps the synthesis of local control and communication protocols to an optimization problem. The project contributes to the nascent area of temporal logic inference by developing a machine learning method to learn temporal logic classifiers from large amounts of data. Novel abstraction and verification techniques for stochastic dynamical systems are defined and used to verify the correctness of the gene circuits in the BDA workflow.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diamagnetically levitated nanoliter fluid handling multirobot system

We developed a small scale robotic system to deliver nanoliter fluid volumes with micrometer-scale precision. The Microfactory platform was developed in collaboration with SRI International and is capable of driving robots at high velocity as well as precisely and stably positioning end effectors with submicrometer precision. We built upon previous work on diamagnetically levitated robots driven by magnetic forces generated by current traces in underlying printed circuit boards, and designed robots to be directly integrated on a microscope stage, enabling both course control of large-scale movements and precision tracking via the optical microscope.

The fluid pipetting technique takes advantage of the dominance of forces due to surface tension at small scales. We use passive capillary-driven flow for loading micropipettes and characterize the rate of loading. For capillary tubes and micropipettes, this means that fluids can be loaded relying only on Laplace pressure. The pipette aperture, molecular concentration and dwell time can be chosen to control the transfer of molecular species. We visually demonstrate diffusive release with fluorescent cargo as it infuses a hydrogel substrate. Further, we demonstrate fine-scale induction of engineered cells with signaling molecules. These tasks may be parallelized with up to four independently actuated robots carrying different cargo.

Robot-cell communication via synthetic biology

We showed that small scale robots can be used to facilitate biomolecular communication over long distances.  Long-range transport is enabled via magnetic actuation of a soft robot capable of encapsulating engineered cells and/or signaling molecules. The work utilized a well-studied cell signaling system called quorum sensing which is often used to investigate cell-to-cell communication and cell population dynamics. In this system, genetically engineered receiver cells are programmed to sense a biochemical signal that is synthesized and secreted by sender cells. We investigated two methodologies for robot-cell communication. In the first, a helical-shaped robot composed of a porous, biological hydrogel embedded with iron oxide is infused with the signaling molecule and is driven using a uniform, rotating magnetic field over a lawn of receiver cells. In the second, sender cells are cultured on the robot and transported to a target area of receiver cells. The signaling molecules diffuse to the local environment, which triggers genetic expression of fluorescent proteins in the receiver population.

On-board chemical actuators and biosensors

We synthetically engineered quorum sensing networks in bacteria which form the basis of organic microrobotic sensing and processing units. Biosensors produce, detect and respond to extracellular small molecule chemical signals. We further used optogenetic tools to engineer our biosensors to produce chemical stimuli on-demand in response to a light stimulus. We developed a deterministic reaction-diffusion mathematical model to guide future design decisions and to characterize system performance. For instance, we characterize the dosage required to trigger sensor readout, the time delay to generate sensor readout after signal detection, and the spatial range over which a signal from a chemical actuator is produced. We further compared our mathematical model to experiments. We showed that these biosensors can be used as a two-way communication platform between microrobots and their local environment, where the receipt of signals (i.e. chemical ?messages?) is confirmed via production of fluorescent reporters.

Functional soft micro bio robots for autonomous biological experiments

We designed and demonstrated milliscale soft, biocompatible robots having spherical or cylindrical geometric features such that traverse 2D semi-solid cellular culture substrates within petri dishes. We embedded living chemical actuators or biosensors on-board which deliver and receive signals from the robot?s microenvironment. Further, we implemented closed-loop feedback control with multiplexed signal inputs to control robot motion and trigger production from on-board chemical actuators. We fabricated a set of tri-axial nested Helmholtz coils to produce rotating magnetic fields, and control robots in two dimensions by varying the orientation of the rotating field, while keeping its magnitude and frequency constant. On-board light-triggerable chemical actuators are activated using spatial light patterning from a digital micromirror display (DMD) enabling triggered production and release of signaling molecules.
